item.title: Apfeld Lab Projects (2015-Present)
item.description: I began my work in the Apfeld lab in October 2015. At that time, the lab was brand new and the wet lab space had not been set up yet. I briefly worked on learning and writing tutorials related to the analysis of spacial oxidization patterns in C. elegans, and we’ll come back to that in 2019. I got into the wet lab in February 2016. After learning the ropes, I began investigating the relationships between different transcription factors related to aging.

item.title: Connecting a remote MongoDB database with R/Shiny
item.description: While making a Shiny App for a lab project (Sensor Overlord), I wanted to create a feature where users could input sensor data into a database, where it could be accessible to other users. I decided to give MongoDB a shot, mostly becuase of the free hosting services available on MongoDB’s website. And it was actually extremely straightforward. There are great resources available online, like the mongolite user manual and the shiny persistent data storage page.

item.title: What Buzzfeed Quizzes have to do with Ratiometric Microscopy
item.description: Science is notoriously poorly communicated. I was recently browsing the DePace Lab Website and it linked me to a fantastic video called “Teaching Matters” by Professor Andrew Murray. My interest in science communication is nothing new, but the video nonetheless made me think twice about how I’m presenting my research. Not only does science need to be communicated to the public (who funds most university research) but it also needs to be better communicated to other scientists, especially those who may benefit from the research but who are in tangential fields with different jargon.

item.title: About
item.description: Hi, I’m Julian. I’m a young researcher and I’ll graduate with a B.S. in Biology in June 2019 and an M.S. in Bioinformatics in May 2020 from Northeastern University. I would like to study the genetics and molecular biology of living things. Increasingly, that field involves more and more computation and, with the increased ability to model processes iteratively, the systems-level approach to molecular biology seems really promising. So I’m working on building and using bioinformatics and computational biology tools and models so that I can learn more new things about how life works.

item.title: Experience using Blogdown with Minimal template
Written subject tutorials
item.description: Genomania https://genomania.gitbook.io A guidebook for common tools in genomics and bioinformatics. For Reals Math https://for-reals.gitbook.io/ Written tutorials covering select topics from calculus (through multivariable integration), linear algebra, and real analysis. ReadableAlgo https://readablealgo.gitbook.io Tutorials for common algorithmic problems and their solutions, along with some theory lessons.
